summary:
Juanita is a Urban Living Lab Developer at the AMS institute. She is passionate about cities, architecture, sustainability and inclusion, and her interest is to investigate how technology and urban innovation can provide solutions to address complex urban challenges.

Her background combines her domain knowledge in urban planning and architecture with working experience in Living Labs, smart cities, mobility and technology (data, map-based visualizations and simulations, sensors, models, applications). In the projects she translates the needs and challenges of internal and external stakeholders into project scope, and requirements. During project execution, she guides the co-creation and testing activities by providing domain-specific input and validating the output. 

She was previously involved in the  in the H2020 URBANAGE and the H2020 INDIMO, CityFlows and the TOKEN projects as an Urban Design Researcher at imec.

Until 2018 she was a CityScience Advisor for the City Science Group, at the MIT Media Lab, in the context of the "Andorra Living Lab" initiative, coordinating projects in urban simulation, cultural heritage, and education.

treasury_media.title: Entre calles, arquitecturas y emociones la ciudad percibida | Juanita Devis | TEDxAndorraLaVella

profile_positions.title: Urban Living Lab Developer

profile_positions.description:
Researcher in SMIT IMEC VUB, working on European and regional projects to investigate the use of technology for more inclusive cities.

/Contribution 
Project coordination
Developing and executing co-creation activities for inclusive technologies and technologies to support inclusion
Research on inclusive smart cities (urban planning, data, mobility, sensors)
Project proposals

/Projects

URBANAGE is a European Horizon 2020 project that investigates how digital technology can address the needs of ageing people in the urban environment.  A Digital Twin data-driven decision-support tool, to be adopted by public servants and other stakeholders will be developed, combining multidimensional Big Data analysis, models and simulations with Artificial Intelligence algorithms, and visualizations. 

INDIMO is a European Horizon 2020 project that aims to break the barriers that vulnerable people face in accessing digitally interconnected transport systems.

The COOCK|OPEN STAD project funded by VLAIO, brings together the expertise of 7 knowledge institutes on data management, data disclosure, data standardization, and environmental factors to enable companies to translate knowledge and best practices and apply them into business cases.
profile_positions.title: Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Researcher of the imec EDiT (Enabling Digital Transformation) division, working on innovative projects to address the current and future urban, mobility and logistics challenges of the Flemish region. 
 
/Contributions
  •Urban Domain expert in the team.
  •H2020 Token Pioneer Use Case (PUC) Lead: Dynamic Access to the city 
  •Coordination of the research activities with University groups (AAA CityFlows Project)
  •Transforming high-level requirements into new prioritized features to be developed.
  •Project scoping and refinement
  •GIS Data mapping and data assessment
  •Co-development of prototypes and demonstrators for early validation
  •Writing project proposals, deliverables, and technical reports
  •Development CityFlows validation App and coordination of the validation activities of the model
  •Presenting projects at external and internal events.
  •Research and Proposal of WAD (Walkable Acceptable Distance) model as Digital Twin use case
 
/Projects

  //CityFlows
 
The CityFlows project combines urban planning, sensor fusion, hydrodynamical modeling and data analysis to investigate and visualize the flows of people, bikes, cars, public transportation in the urban environment by fusing mobility-related data streams including cameras, motion sensors and wifi scanners.
 
 
  //TOKEN H2020 EU Project 
 
The goal of TOKEN is to investigate Transformative impact of blockchain in technologies in public services. The “Dynamic access to the city and last mile (food) logistics” use case investigates how to promote last mile deliveries and local economy in the city of Leuven by granting access to the city and parking services on the basis of sustainable practices. 

 
  //Digital Twin

The digital twin is a decision-making tool for visualizing, prototyping and simulate “what-if” scenarios of cities. It is a tool that allow different stakeholders, to take well informed decisions about interventions in cities and their impact.
